sen.j: 後嵯峨天皇（ごさがてんのう、承久2年2月26日（1220年4月1日） - 文永9年2月17日（1272年3月17日））は、鎌倉時代の第88代天皇（在位：仁治3年1月20日（1242年2月21日） - 寛元4年1月29日（1246年2月16日））。
sen.e: Emperor Gosaga (April 1st, 1220 - March 17th, 1272) was the eighty eighth Emperor during the Kamakura period. (his reign was February 21st, 1242 - February 16th, 1246.)
Emperor Gosaga (April 1st, 1220 - March 17th, 1272) was the eighty eighth Emperor during the Kamakura period. (his reign was from February 21st, 1242 to February 16th, 1246.)
Emperor Gosaga (April 1, 1220 - March 17, 1272) was the eighty eighth Emperor during the Kamakura period (his reign was from February 21, 1242 to February 16, 1246).
sen.cmt: 日付表記ピリオドの位置

sen.j: 諱は邦仁（くにひと）。
sen.e: His posthumous name was Kunihito.
His posthumous name was Kunihito.
His posthumous name was Kunihito.

sen.j: 土御門天皇の第二皇子。
sen.e: He was the second Prince of Emperor Tsuchimikado.
He was the second Prince of Emperor Tsuchimikado.
He was the second Prince of Emperor Tsuchimikado.

sen.j: 母は、土御門通宗の娘、源通子。
sen.e: His mother was Emperor Tsuchimikado's daughter, MINAMORO no Tsushi. (Michiko)
His mother was Emperor Tsuchimikado's daughter, MINAMORO no Tsushi. (Michiko)
His mother was Michimune TSUCHIMIKADO's daughter, MINAMOTO no Tsushi (Michiko).

sen.j: 土御門上皇が土佐に流された後は、母方の大叔父である中院通方・土御門定通の許で育った。
sen.e: After the retired Emperor was sentenced to deportation to Tosa Province, he was raised by his mother's great uncle, Nakanoin Michikata, Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO.
After the retired Emperor was banished to Tosa Province, he was raised by his mother's great uncle, Nakanoin Michikata, Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO.
After the Retired Emperor Tsuchimikado was banished to Tosa Province, he was raised by his mother's great uncle, Nakanoin Michikata, Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO.

sen.j: だが、土御門家一門の没落に伴って苦しい生活を送り、20歳を過ぎても出家も元服もままならないという中途半端な状態に置かれていた。
sen.e: However his life was not easy under the condition of the Tsuchimikado family being ruined, he was left in the unclear situation not being able to have a coming-of-age ceremony after he was twenty years old.
However, his life was not easy dur to the Tsuchimikado family being ruined, he was left in a state of confusion not even being able to have a coming-of-age ceremony after he was twenty years old.
However, his life was not easy due to the Tsuchimikado family being ruined, he was left in a state of confusion not even being able to have a coming-of-age ceremony after he was twenty years old.

sen.j: ところが四条天皇が12歳で急死したため、皇位継承の問題が持ち上がった。
sen.e: But after Emperor Shijo died suddenly when he was twelve years old, it caused the issue of the Imperial succession.
But after Emperor Shijo died suddenly, when he was just twelve years old, it raised the issue of Imperial succession.
But after Emperor Shijo died suddenly, when he was just twelve years old, it raised the issue of Imperial succession.

sen.j: 公卿や鎌倉幕府などの思惑が絡んだため、問題は難航した。
sen.e: The issue ran into difficulties since the Court nobles and the Kamakura government both had their own expectations.
The issue ran into difficulties because the Court nobles and the Kamakura government both had different expectations.
The issue ran into difficulties because the Court nobles and the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) both had different expectations.
sen.cmt: government→bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)

sen.j: 九条道家ら公卿勢力は、順徳天皇の皇子である忠成王（仲恭天皇の異母弟）を擁立しようとしたが、執権北条泰時は、承久の乱の関係者の順徳上皇の皇子の擁立には反対の立場を示し、中立的立場であった土御門上皇の皇子の邦仁王を擁立しようとし、鶴岡八幡宮の御託宣があったとして邦仁王を擁立した（実は土御門定通の妻は泰時の異母妹であったため、邦仁王と北条氏とは縁戚関係にあったという特殊な事情もあった）。
sen.e: Michiie KUJO from one of the Court noble force, tried Prince Tadanari (Emperor Chukyo's half younger brother), Emperor Juntoku's Prince, to succeed to the throne, however the regent, Yasutoki HOJO was against it since Emperor Juntoku's Prince was involved in the Jokyu Disturbance, he tried retired Emperor Tsuchimikado's Prince, Prince Kunihito to become Emperor and let the Prince enthroned by saying he received an oracle from Tsurugaoka Hachiman-gu Shrine.

Michiie KUJO from one of the Court noble forces, tried to have Prince Tadanari (Emperor Chukyo's half younger brother), Emperor Juntoku's Prince, succeed to the throne, however, the regent, Yasutoki HOJO was against it since Emperor Juntoku's Prince was involved in the Jokyu Disturbance, he then tried to have retired Emperor Tsuchimikado's Prince, Prince Kunihito become Emperor and allowed the Prince enthroned by saying he received an oracle from Tsurugaoka Hachiman-gu Shrine.

Michiie KUJO from one of the Court noble forces, tried to have Prince Tadanari (Emperor Chukyo's half younger brother), Emperor Juntoku's Prince, succeed to the throne, however, the regent, Yasutoki HOJO was against it since Retired Emperor Juntoku's Prince was involved in the Jokyu Disturbance, he then tried to have Retired Emperor Tsuchimikado's Prince, Prince Kunihito become Emperor and allowed the Prince to be enthroned by saying he received an oracle from Tsurugaoka Hachiman-gu Shrine (In fact, Sadamichi TSUCHIMIKADO's wife was Yasutoki's half younger sister, thus there was an unusual situation whereby the Prince Kunihito and Hojo clan were relatives to each others).
sen.cmt: 上皇の表記「（実は土御門定通の妻は泰時の異母妹であったため、邦仁王と北条氏とは縁戚関係にあったという特殊な事情もあった）。」を訳出しました。

sen.j: この駆け引きのため、11日間の空位期間が発生した。
sen.e: Due to the above tactics, there was an interregnum for eleven days.
Due to the above tactics, there was an interregnum for eleven days.
Due to the above tactics, there was an interregnum for eleven days.

sen.j: 邦仁王は1242年即位し、1246年、在位4年で後深草天皇に譲位。
sen.e: Prince Kunihito succeeded to the throne in 1242, he was in power for four years and passed the throne to Emperor Gofukakusa.
Prince Kunihito succeeded to the throne in 1242, he was in power for four years and passed the throne to Emperor Gofukakusa.
Prince Kunihito succeeded to the throne in 1242, he was in power for four years and passed the throne to Emperor Gofukakusa in 1246.

sen.j: 以後、院政を敷く。
sen.e: After that the retired Emperor ruled the cloister government.
After that the retired Emperor ruled the cloistered government.
After that the Retired Emperor ruled the cloistered government.
sen.cmt: "the retired Emperor"→"the Retired Emperor"に変更しました。

sen.j: この年、政治的に対立関係にあった実力者・九条道家が失脚した事もあって、以後上皇の主導によって朝廷内の政務が行われる事になった。
sen.e: After his opposition who was a powerful political man, Michiie KUJO lost his position, the retired Emperor took control of the politics inside the Imperial Palace.
After his opposition, who was a powerful politician, Michiie KUJO lost his position, the retired Emperor took control of the politics inside the Imperial Palace.
After his opposition, who was a powerful politician, Michiie KUJO lost his position, the retired Emperor took control of the politics inside the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 以後、姉小路顕朝・中御門経任ら実務担当の中級貴族を側近に登用されて院政が展開されていく事になる。
sen.e: Since then Akitomo ANEGAKOJI and Tsuneto NAKAMIKADO who were middle class court nobles, were appointed as close aides to the retired Emperor to run day-to day running of the Palace to proceed the cloister government.

Since then Akitomo ANEGAKOJI and Tsuneto NAKAMIKADO who were middle class court nobles, were appointed as close aides to the retired Emperor to run day-to day operations of the Palace to fruther the cloistered government.

Since then Akitomo ANEGAKOJI and Tsuneto NAKAMIKADO who were middle class court nobles, were appointed as close aides to the retired Emperor to run day-to-day operations of the Palace to further the cloistered government.

sen.j: 1259年には後深草天皇に対し、後深草天皇の弟である亀山天皇への譲位を促した。
sen.e: In 1259 the retired Emperor implied Emperor Gofukakusa to pass the throne to his brother, Emperor Kameyama.
In 1259 the retired Emperor urged that Emperor Gofukakusa pass the throne to his brother, Emperor Kameyama.
In 1259 the retired Emperor urged that Emperor Gofukakusa pass the throne to his brother, Emperor Kameyama.

sen.j: 後嵯峨上皇の時代は、鎌倉幕府による朝廷掌握が進んだ時期であり、後嵯峨上皇による院政は、ほぼ幕府の統制下にあった。
sen.e: During the retired Emperor Gosaga's reign, the Kamakura Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun) tried to control the Imperial Palace, the cloister government ruled by the retired Emperor Gosaga was almost regulated by the government.

During the retired Emperor Gosaga's reign, the Kamakura Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun) tried to control the Imperial Palace, the cloistered government ruled by the retired Emperor Gosaga was mostly regulated by the government.

During the Retired Emperor Gosaga's reign, the Kamakura bakufu tried to control the Imperial Palace, the cloistered government ruled by the Retired Emperor Gosaga was mostly regulated by the government.
sen.cmt: (Japanese feudal government headed by a Shogun) 既出なので削除上皇の表記

sen.j: また、摂家の代わりに、宗尊親王を将軍として送っている。
sen.e: Also Imperial Prince Munetaka was sent as Shogun instead of the clan (family) eligible for regents.
Also, the Imperial Prince, Munetaka, was sent as Shogun instead of the clan (family) eligible for regent positions.
Also, the Imperial Prince, Munetaka, was sent as Shogun instead of the family eligible for regent positions.

sen.j: 以後、鎌倉幕府の将軍は天皇家より出ることになる。
sen.e: After this Shogun of the Kamakura bakufu came from the Imperial family.
After this, the Shogun of the Kamakura bakufu came from the Imperial family.
After this, the Shogun of the Kamakura bakufu came from the Imperial family.

sen.j: また、この時代に北条氏が鎌倉幕府を掌握し、執権政治を確立する。
sen.e: During this period the Hojo clan took control of the Kamakura bakufu and established the regency politics.
During this period the Hojo clan took control of the Kamakura bakufu and established regency politics.
During this period the Hojo clan took control of the Kamakura bakufu and established regency politics.

sen.j: 1268年に出家して法皇となり大覚寺に移る。
sen.e: He became a Cloister Emperor who had joined a Buddhist order in 1268 and moved to Daikaku-ji Temple.
He became a Cloistered Emperor who had joined a Buddhist order in 1268 and moved to Daikaku-ji Temple.
He became a Cloistered Emperor who had joined a Buddhist order in 1268 and moved to Daikaku-ji Temple.
He died in 1272.
He died in 1272.
He died in 1272.

sen.j: 後嵯峨上皇が、後深草天皇の皇子ではなく、亀山天皇の皇子（後の後宇多天皇）を皇太子にした事が、後の持明院統（後深草天皇の血統）と大覚寺統（亀山天皇の血統）の確執のきっかけとなり、それが南北朝時代、更には後南朝まで続く大乱の源となった。
sen.e: The retired Emperor Gosaga appointed Emperor Kameyama's Prince (later called Emperor Gouda) as Crown Prince, instead of appointing Emperor Gofukakusa's Prince, it caused the conflict between what it's called the Jimyo-in Imperial line (Emperor Gofukakusa's line) and the Daikaku-ji Imperial line (Emperor Kameyama's line) in later years, it also caused the big battle of the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties and even the post Southern Dynasties.
sen.cmt: 持明院統→the Jimyo-in Imperial line[定訳不明] 大覚寺統→the Daikaku-ji Imperial line[定訳不明] 後南朝→[定訳不明]
sen.e: The retired Emperor Gosaga appointed Emperor Kameyama's Prince (later called Emperor Gouda) as Crown Prince, instead of appointing Emperor Gofukakusa's Prince, and this caused a conflict between what it's called the Jimyo-in Imperial line (Emperor Gofukakusa's line) and the Daikaku-ji Imperial line (Emperor Kameyama's line) in later years, it also caused the big battle during the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties and even the post Southern Dynasties.

The Retired Emperor Gosaga appointed Emperor Kameyama's Prince (later called Emperor Gouda) as Crown Prince, instead of appointing Emperor Gofukakusa's Prince, and this caused a conflict between what it's called the Jimyo-in Imperial line (Emperor Gofukakusa's line) and the Daikaku-ji Imperial line (Emperor Kameyama's line) in later years, it also caused the big battle during the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan) and even the post Southern Court.
sen.cmt: the period of the Northern and Southern Dynasties→the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan)Southern Dynasties→Southern Court

sen.j: 吉川英治は『私本太平記』中で「天子の座は象徴で、治天の君たる上皇、法皇にこそ実権がある、というのは既に常識であった。
sen.e: In "Shihon Taihei ki" (the Record of Great peace), Eiji YOSHIKAWA mentioned, 'It was common sense that the emperors did not rule the government, instead, Chiten no kimi, the retired emperors and the cloister emperors who has joined a Buddhist order, took actual control of the politics.
sen.cmt: 私本太平記』→Shihon Taihei ki(the Record of Great peace)[定訳不明]
sen.e: In "Shihon Taihei ki" (the Record of Great peace), Eiji YOSHIKAWA mentioned, 'It was common sense for emperors not to rule the government, instead, Chiten no kimi, the retired emperors and the cloister emperors who had joined a Buddhist order, took the actual control of the politics.

In "Shihon Taihei ki" (the Record of Great peace), Eiji YOSHIKAWA mentioned, 'It was common sense for emperors not to rule the government, instead, Chiten no kimi, the retired emperors and the cloister emperors who had joined a Buddhist order, took the actual control of the politics.

sen.j: この無理な処置は少しでも長く院政の権栄を享受したいがためであろう。」と考察している。
sen.e: This unnatural measures were organized to continue and have power by ruling the cloister government for longer possible time', he inquired.
These unnatural measures were organized for the continuation of power by ruling the cloistered government for the longest possible time.'
These unnatural measures were organized for the continuation of power by ruling the cloistered government for the longest possible time.'
Ninji (January 9, 1242) - February 26, 1243
Ninji (January 9, 1242) - February 26, 1243
Ninji (January 9, 1242) - February 26, 1243
Kangen February 26, 1243 - (January 19, 1246)
Kangen February 26, 1243 - (January 19, 1246)
Kangen February 26, 1243 - (January 19, 1246)

sen.j: 京都市右京区嵯峨天龍寺芒ノ馬場町の嵯峨南陵（さがのみなみのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Sagano Minami ni Misasagi at Susuki no Baba-cho Town, Saga Tenryu-ji, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed in Sagano Minami ni Misasagi at Susuki no Baba-cho Town, Saga Tenryu-ji, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed in Sagano Minami no Misasagi at Susuki no Baba-cho, Saga Tenryu-ji, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City.
